fields.description: As a cloud user and developer, I want to configure and run SSH daemon on my Windows instance so that I can run automated QA against it and use the familiar ssh client to diagnose.
fields.summary: Support for SSHD in Windows VM

comments.body:
More info...

The problem: 
QA needs a method to interact remotely and directly with Windows guests running in Eucalyptus via a Linux server.  

More info...
At this point I do not think this will need Engineering work to achieve. Our current plan is to create a set of base  images without any Eucalyptus specific software and install Cygwin for ssh (if needed). We will likely have a separate story to track the next steps involving creating Eucalyptus tool'd images from these base images. 

Some background on the SSH portion...
We are attempting to improve our current Windows QA env by:
-eliminating debug and failure points, 
-reusing test code that is not 'Windows' specific, 
-expedite testing, debugging, and development of 'Windows Guest tests' in Eucalyptus. 

We have been investigating SSH, Telnet, and Powershell. 

QA currently uses Power shell to do the majority of our Windows testing, however we execute most of the Powershell from a Linux server via ssh.   
Like Eucalyptus, our automated tests/test environment runs on Linux. We currently use an 'ssh to power shell' proxy to test windows. This involves a Linux server executing a test against a Linux cloud that is running a Windows Guest, the Linux server is executing power shell commands/scripts on a remote windows server to then test the remote Windows guest. Most of these tests are also using SSH to the Eucalyptus components to query status, provide debug information, or execute the non-Windows Guest specific portion of the tests. Querying the Linux portion of the system via SSH is often the majority of the test, and test development. 

I have been unable to find a decent way to run remote Powershell from a Linux server, and so far Cygwin seems to provide the best environment for the SSH portion on Windows. 

Thanks,
-M

To add to [~mclark] comments, one motivation to package cygwin/sshd with the windows tool was to enable eutester with windows VM (possibly for use by customers). I agree that for our own use by QA, we don't need engineering work. The engineer work would be to package cygwin and run setup.exe in attended mode, plus setting up sshd config. This work can be done manually for building base image.

Just curious - do we test Active Directory against the Windows instances?  If so, why not use the Active Directory server to be the driver for the tests?  From what I have seen in the field, anyone deploying a Windows instance has it tied to Active Directory if they are running the instances in production.

Regarding adding a cygwin/sshd package that can be installed with the Windows Integration Tool - anyone who is running a Windows instance in production won't have cygwin and/or SSHD enabled.  Unfortunately, if you are doing Windows in production, you are all in (i.e. do everything the Windows way).  IMO, if we can have a set of PowerShell scripts that we can use, and share with customers, this will help improve our Windows support story tremendously.  

I understand the case for making it easier for QA testing, but don't we want to test what customers will do?  I know it may seem like an extra step (and dependency), but wouldn't it help us in the long run if we are able to test what customers will do in production?

The need for 'Linux' remote access is to optimize automated QA. 
Adding a set of desired points on the solution. (The solution does not have to be SSH.)

1)Text based for automation
2)Direct remote interaction with the guest 
3)Runs on a Linux server. 
4 Debug-able through logs after execution of a test. If the test has to be re-run or run outside of the automated env in order to debug, than we lose most of our benefit. 
5)Ideally this remote access method would exist and be usable w/o any Eucalyptus software to allow us to test any software created by Eucalyptus, ...outside Eucalyptus.

Testing AD is a requirement as it is part of the tool testing. This is also a good reason to have a separate debugging method for QA which has little to no reliance upon AD. 

 [~spark] has done a good job of creating a test environment that does pretty much everything in a 'Windows' way. We hope to continue using most of this and adding to it. However, even in this current env cygwin SSH is still installed on a Windows server acting as a proxy and ssh is in the test path. The Powershell scripts can be executable directly in Windows  w/o ssh though. They will lose the benefit of interrogating or exercising actions on the entire Linux system (ie Eucalyptus) concurrently  via ssh though.  
 
Our test scripts (including the powershell scripts) should be available with our test suites.  If they are not I'll post them to Eutester. Currently the Windows test env requires a HW component(s) including an ssh proxy and AD server(s) with static configuration so they may not be that useful/portable outside of our env. 
I agree there is a lot of value in testing actual use cases. Time and licensing allowing, some additional 'dog-food-ish' use cases would be good.  
Thanks!
-M
Adding to [~mclark], sshd + powershell will be a nice combination, where sshd is used to inject the powershell script (that we currently have) and run the tests inside the VM directly.

[~hspencer] the major motivation is to get rid of windows proxy, which listens on SSHD and dispatches powershell scripts to Windows VMs. The QA guys want to interrogate the VMs directly and it requires SSHD  running on windows VM. AD tests will continue to run via a separate windows server. The existence of proxy has nothing to do with customer environment. IMO, it won't affect the current and future customers (or affect positively if we run more QA and improve code quality).

[~hspencer] we have not tested Linux wmi client. I see two problems:
  -- It is a hack. More hack than cygwin sshd. I'd take safer path.
  -- Even if it works, 'wmi' is an awkward, hard-to-maintain way to program the QA scripts.

[~spark], are you saying its a "hack" from a Linux point of view or Windows point of view?  From a Windows point of view, using WMI is much more preferred than SSHD to communicate to a Windows machine.  For supporting communicating from a Linux server to a Windows image, hacking is going to be involved anyway.  Regarding safety, I didn't know we are security was being taken into account here.  If so, what security limitations are being enforced?

[~hspencer] I didn't mean the security when I said "hack". Sorry for the confusion. ssh is a standard protocol while wmi is MS' proprietary protocol and that's why wmi linux client is a hack. In addition we already tested and confirmed cygwin/sshd solution. Again, this story is NOT about addressing customer issue. It is about QA.

[~spark], exactly it is about QA.  Don't we want to test what customers will do in QA?  If we don't, then I misheard and/or misunderstand what types of tests we run in QA and apologize.  If we don't want to test what customers are/will do based off of best practices in QA, then lets document what are the requirements of the test cases.  I wouldn't want to put tests in that are extra work and wouldn't be expected to be part of the various QA tests.

Yes, SSH is a standard protocol, but not a protocol natively supported by Windows.  WMI is MS proprietary protocol - as you stated - hence will make sure we are using MS protocols to do MS testing.  Just curious, have we looked at if we use cygwin/SSH on a Windows image - will it keep us from not being able to reproduce an issue that is seen by a customer?  What I mean here is that if cygwin/SSH need to run on the images, do we know that the policies associated with allowing them to run and execute will affect other applications we test on our Windows images?

Thank you guys for the input!
We'll probably use ssh in the near term as it's the easiest to transition QA tests to but might as well add the other tools now as well. For the first round of base images I'm going to try to install/configure the following tools, they'll be there for future use and test development if/as we need them.
Thanks! -M

- cygwin + ssh
- wmi
- winexe
- nagios

Thanks [~mclark]. These tools are going to be part of the base image that we will be using for QA, and not automatically installed via the Windows integration tool that our users will use to create their Windows images. Is that understanding correct?
[~mclark], no problem.  Thanks for providing the forum for the discussion.

Can I ask why we're using sshd and not a native solution that likely has better stability? Remote powershell is available without SSHD and without RDP.  You can use WinRM service.  

http://technet.microsoft.com/en-us/magazine/ff700227.aspx


(Yes you can use PASH on linux to talk to powershell on windows: https://blogs.msdn.com/b/powershell/archive/2008/04/08/powershell-on-linux-solaris-mac-etc.aspx?Redirected=true )

[~shashi] We have at least one new round of Windows testing prior to 3.4, mainly to test the integration tool. At least this will be a manual effort.  

[~dfederlein]  Thanks. I've been following PASH for long time now (~2 years) waiting to see if the project would be revived. It looked pretty much dead until very recently. Looks like there's some recent activity in the project. Would be awesome if/when PASH becomes stable, that would be ideal. I'll take it out for another test drive. 

Re remote pshell...
We currently use remote Powershell through a proxy, and as mentioned before this still requires cygwin on Windows and SSH.  This adds an unnecessary point of failure and maintenance given our Linux based automated test environment, also makes the tests/test env a bit less portable. We  plan to continue to use Powershell so assuming we'll be ready to support remote Powershell via Windows, and/or with something like PASH when/if it's ready and stable without needing to rebuild our test images.

Wanted to note that during investigation of all these tools, many blogs do mention ssh as a viable alternative for 'Linux driven remote Windows access' to the tool(s) in discussion. I'm hoping to build this latest base set of 'test' images so that use of ssh now should not prevent us from developing tests which utilize other remote access methods in the future. 
Big thanks for this discussion!
-M
